It goes to liyan—and that is what we in This Place are trying to do. Not only create good feelings in the Australian population, but to create what we call in our Yawuru language—liyan ngarn—coming together of both our spirits, in a way that is respectful.
The second thing we talk about in Yawuru is mabu ngarrungunil—good community. Good people to live with. Good society. A good race of human beings.
And that is what we are also talking about in the referendum. A good nation. A population of people with the best and highest interest, for the care of everyone and for the betterment of everyone.
And the third thing we talk about in Yawuru is what we call mabu buru—that is good country. A good place. A better world, a safer world, a better economy.

But a place, where we and all Australians can enjoy our environment and grow up knowing we have a rightful place, having resolved the differences between the First Peoples and ourselves, as we go towards the Makarrata.

I am deeply grateful to Senator Dodson for providing his contribution for me to include in my remarks this evening, and I want to underline the opportunity his words reveal. I urge those in the 'no' campaign, arguing against the Voice, to meet that opportunity, to not use the soul and fabric of our nation as a political battleground, to resist putting political self-interest over the national interest, because we must have greater ambition not just to close the gap but to achieve our full potential as a nation, and we can only fulfil our potential when every Australian has a chance to realise their own.
The closing line of the Uluru statement said:
We invite you to walk with us in a movement of the Australian people for a better future.

I would like to invite those in the 'no' campaign and those opposite to reconsider this ask. 'We invite you'; it is a gracious and patient ask of us as Australians. It is an ask seeded by a grassroots movement and the culmination of years of discussion, consultation and hard work, including consultation with 1,200 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It is an ask supported by eight in 10 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.

Already, this gracious call has been answered by organisations across Australia—faith groups, sporting clubs, national sporting codes, universities, the business sector, trade unions. The call has been answered by every single premier and chief minister across the political spectrum. We have an opportunity to vote 'yes' for constitutional recognition, to vote 'yes' for the form in which it has been requested—a voice to parliament. We have an opportunity to vote 'yes' for that better future. With the hope that this call for empowerment will be answered with the same ambition and grace with which it was issued, I commend this bill to the Senate.

Senator BROCKMAN (Western Australia) (19:41): As we all rise in this place to speak on this bill, the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023, we all bring unique perspectives and we all probably reflect on our own backgrounds, our own experiences, our own history. In thinking about my position on the referendum, I couldn't help but go back to the tales my father told me and the interactions I had with Aboriginal stockmen on our coastal lease west of our farm in Pemberton—in particular with one good friend of Dad's, Charlie Burns. Charlie was a remarkable character, a real legend in the Manjimup-Pemberton area. Charlie was the first Aboriginal boy to go to Guilford Grammar School. He served in World War I in the 10th Light Horse Regiment. He was recognised for his gallantry in his service to the nation. He was a great friend of my father's. He spent many months, probably even years, out on the coastal leases on horseback, camping rough with my father, and led the most remarkable life. He was certainly welcome at our dinner table and was a close friend of my father's, but he also dined in the Governor-General's house in Western Australia—a remarkable life. I say this not to pretend that the past was better than it was or that Charlie didn't face racism in his life—I have absolutely no doubt that he did—but to say that I was raised to always look to the individual, to always look to what the individual brought to the conversation, to always consider the value of humanity as based on that individual value of the person.

This bill will easily pass parliament; that has been clear for a long time. And that is right. It is up to the Australian people to make judgements as to the nature and the words that make up the Australian Constitution. But I will vote 'no' in the referendum, and I wish to put on the record why that is so. The Australian Constitution is the fundamental bedrock of our democracy. It is the foundation upon which our democratic and legal institutions sit, and from which our society has grown. We must take any change to that foundation with the utmost seriousness.

Our Constitution is a living document; it's designed to accommodate change. But that change has to be made thoughtfully and that change to our great federation has to be made by the majority of Australians, but also by a majority of states. This was an important provision that reflected our desire, Australia's desire, to preserve our institutions, to avoid changing our Constitution unless strongly supported by most Australians. In practice, changing our Constitution requires a supermajority. This has prevented significant overreach by governments in the past.

You don't have to look far through the list of failed constitutional amendments to see that the Australian people have a lot of common sense in this regard. For example, we would have seen a significant, an unprecedented growth in Commonwealth influence if it had been given the power to take control of any industry or corporation deemed to be monopolistic. Australians, in their wisdom, defeated this attempted overreach. Another example: the referendum in the early phase of the Cold War to give specific Commonwealth power to regulate communism. This was defeated, at perhaps one of the tensest points of that war, because the Australian people were wary of giving government more power to control political thought.

We, as a Western democracy, are a part of the great Enlightenment tradition. The Enlightenment ideals—the need to separate and limit power; checks and balances to avoid the tyranny of the majority; equality of the individual as a key source of freedom; a robust federalism—turned sceptical ideas into a robust and meaningful set of institutions—our parliaments, our courts and, at the heart of Australia, our Constitution. Enlightenment thinkers distrusted mob rule and revered the rule of law. The Enlightenment project is the origin of the modern world and of modern Australia, but it has never claimed perfection. That is why we need mechanisms like referenda; to give us the ability to change, albeit with caution, our foundational document.

As my good friend Senator Paterson described much better than I could, and I would encourage you all to listen to or read his contribution, there is a stain on our foundational document in the race power. Like Senator Paterson, in preparing for this debate and clarifying my own thoughts, I went back to the constitutional conventions of the 1890s and read the words and the justifications for that race power. From a modern perspective they make uncomfortable reading. For someone who, like me, is a proud defender of our constitutional norms the justification for that power was blatantly racist in nature—not directed at Aboriginal people I should add, but at others mostly outside this country.

Some leading proponents of the Voice today were, just a short decade ago, calling for the repeal of that race power, for it to be taken out of the Constitution. I would endorse that view. Though now, strangely, that has been silenced in the face of this amendment to the Constitution to enshrine a permanent Indigenous Voice to Parliament. So while I acknowledge that stain on our founding document, it is also worth hypothecating for a moment. In one of the first acts of the new Commonwealth, the White Australia Policy was implemented. One of its chief proponents, Chris Watson, first Labor Prime Minister of Australia, used his position on the then crossbench to secure its passage. A few years earlier, he'd tried unsuccessfully to be elected as a Labor Party delegate to the Constitutional Convention. If views like his had had a more prominent position, might we have seen that White Australia Policy more directly enshrined in our Constitution? If so, how and when would it have been removed? The Constitution is difficult to change.

The fact that the race power there is an anachronism. It should go. But, as I have said, the enlightenment project is an ongoing one. Our Constitution can be improved, but the current referendum proposal does not do so. Sadly, it seeks to divide, not unite. It does not elicit universal principles of equality and a steadfast defence of the individual, regardless of heritage. Over the 19th and 20th centuries we've seen many manifestations of anti-enlightenment thought from both the far right and the Left, from fascism to communism. Today's anti-enlightenment movements are less obvious. They reject inquiry and debate as the centrepiece of democracy. Instead, they claim all virtue, as though it comes by way of instinct, as a quasi-mystical driver of our decision-making, and all those who disagree are wrong if not evil. This is the new methodology of the anti-enlightenment. They claim a purity of will while silencing what they deem as unacceptable speech. We need to return to core principles of liberty, progress, toleration, constitutional government, equality, citizenship and primacy of the individual. This constitutional amendment does not achieve those ideals.

Senator HANSON (Queensland—Leader of Pauline Hanson's One Nation) (19:51): I rise to speak to the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023. I'd like to reiterate with people tonight that this is the most important piece of legislation or referendum that will impact on our country since the Constitution was first brought in, in 1901.

One Nation opposes the Voice on principle and in practice. This is because One Nation stands for equality for all Australians. The proposal for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander voice will introduce racial inequality into the Constitution. It is fundamentally wrong. It is a direct attack on the values that support and define one of the most successful and enduring democracies in the world. It is a betrayal of the achievements of Australians who fought for generations to achieve racial equality. It is a brazen and transparent attempt to insert identity politics and all the greedy entitlement and narcissism that goes with it into Australia's founding document. It is an appalling, divisive and racist proposal that should never have seen the light of day.

Not only is it dividing Australia by race; it is dividing Indigenous Australia too. We have been forced to witness some despicable public attacks by leading Voice promoter Noel Pearson on prominent Indigenous Australians who oppose the Voice. His dripping contempt for an opposing view is reflected by the Albanese Labor government.

The government is dishonestly and deceptively doing all it can to ensure a one-sided debate heavily weighted towards the 'yes' campaign. Labor has allocated more than $400 million to a referendum that should only cost about $120 million. Labor is leveraging other government funding to forcibly constrict sports bodies and corporations to support the 'yes' campaign. Labor claims the Voice is necessary to close the gaps but provides absolutely no compelling evidence to support this claim.

The evidence in Australia is to the contrary. Indigenous leaders and organisations have been closely involved in the development of legislation and the design and delivery of Indigenous support programs for decades, and the gaps have not been closed. Despite these failures, they are calling most loudly for the Voice to Parliament so that they can protect this unaccountable Aboriginal industry gravy train in the Constitution for all time. It's all about the money. It's all about pure, naked greed. To pretend anything else would be an insult to the Australian people.

I refer to comments today from the Voice co-design process author Marcia Langton, who said, 'There were sections in the Constitution that could cause Indigenous people harm, and the Voice was needed to address this.' Why not just remove those sections? Instead of inserting racial inequality in the Constitution, why not simply remove the last remaining references to race. These is section 51(xxxvi), the so-called race power, and section 25, which refers to races disqualified from voting. This is the constitutional reform we should be pursuing in the name of genuine equality rather than giving exclusive rights to a small minority of Australians based entirely on race. Let's get rid of these dead letters in the Constitution and move forward together as one people united by our shared identity as Australians.

I'm confident these changes would have support similar to that achieved in the famous 1967 referendum. That referendum was remarkable for two important reasons—more than 90 per cent of voters approved the changes and the Constitution no longer made any distinction between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. All Australians are equal in the Constitution as it stands today. If the Voice referendum is successful, all Australians will not be equal in the Constitution. We must not reverse this important achievement. We must not set our Constitution back more than 50 years. A crucial principle of Australian democracy and Liberal democracies around the world is that all people are essentially equal, regardless of race. The Voice is incompatible with this crucial principle.

Another lie being peddled by the 'yes' camp and Labor is that Australia doesn't recognise Indigenous people. This denies the truth that Indigenous Australians are recognised in many ways—flags, places and names. The National Capital, parliaments and councils commence proceedings with the so-called acknowledgement of country and welcome to country ceremonies at events, including at the drag race meet I attended at Willowbank on the weekend, with politicians all lined up one after the other. Entire government departments are headed by ministers for Indigenous Australians, and there are billions of dollars in taxpayer funding exclusively for Indigenous assistance programs and the celebration of Indigenous artists and sportspeople. There's the fact that more than half of Australia is now under native title, and—there's more!—the Apology to the Stolen Generations. This is just a selection. I'm sure Australians could actually add more and more to that. There is no compelling case for further recognition, let alone by introducing racial inequality in the Constitution.

The constitutional amendment proposed by the Prime Minister has been the subject of more lies by Labor. For months the Prime Minister was assuring Australians that his amendment was modest and could not result in constitutional changes over the scope and powers of the Voice. He assured Australians the High Court would have no role in deciding the Voice's scope and powers, only the parliament would do this, but members of his very own hand-picked referendum working group have directly contradicted him. They confirmed they anticipated the High Court would play a prominent role. They confirmed they were eagerly looking forward to the prospect. Marcia Langton herself has been reported as saying—directly contradicting the Prime Minister again—that, far from being a modest change, the amendment would 'destroy the fabric of the Constitution'. She confirmed, 'That's exactly we're doing.' These are direct threats to Australian democracy and the supremacy of the elected parliament. The prospect of endless activist litigation is very real, strongly supported by a large body of constitutional expert commentary, and even the Attorney-General has finally considered the possibility. We face the prospect of effective representative government being delayed and held hostage by ugly, racially exclusive, black nationalism activists.

That brings me to another clear danger of the Voice: it's just the first step towards what will eventually become a demand for the establishment of a separate, independent, sovereign Indigenous state in Australia, funded entirely by non-Indigenous Australian taxpayers. Most of the ingredients in this recipe for disaster are already there in the Constitution; the final one will go in there if the referendum approves the Voice. I'm warning Australians with regard to this—heed my warning.

Failing this push, the other prospect is what has already happened in New Zealand: the creation of seats in parliament that are reserved exclusively and only for Indigenous people. Labor has already looked at increasing the number of MPs and senators in parliament. It's absolutely no stretch of the imagination that those extra seats in parliament could be demanded and commandeered by the Voice. Remember that it's a voice to parliament, which will happen here in this chamber and which will mean that they could allocate under their legislation to actually set aside seats in this parliament purely based on race. This would just promote more racial inequality, and it's completely unnecessary. We already have 11 members of parliament identifying as Indigenous, which is overrepresentative of Indigenous Australians, who make up around 3.5 per cent of the population—and I believe it's even less than that.

Voice promoters have claimed it will give effect in Australia to the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, including the right to self-determination. This also denies the truth that Indigenous Australians already have as much capacity as the rest of us for self-determination—it's called voting at elections. In fact, every reference to people, voters or electors in the Constitution is entirely inclusive of Indigenous Australians. They are, in this respect, already recognised in the Constitution. This is the way the Constitution should be. The rulebook for governing Australia should make no distinction between citizens based on race. These days, however, modern identity and victimhood politics demands such distinctions.

One of the big problems with this disgusting, racist and socialist movement is Indigenous identity fraud. The government has today refused to acknowledge the truth of Indigenous identity fraud, despite many documented cases of it in Australia over the years. And, I've got to say, it's in the court system, the federal courts—everywhere. But they don't know it's happening. They've turned a blind eye to this. They deny it. However, it is a critical issue that must be resolved before this referendum takes place. Since the government is hell-bent on enshrining exclusive constitutional power based on race, it should at least be making sure that power goes to the right people, not frauds. It must guard against frauds seeking a slice of the Voice's enormous potential power for personal gain. The best way is do this is to establish a robust and objective definition for an Indigenous Australian. My bill to amend the Acts Interpretation Act, which Labor will not support—yes, I said that: Labor will not support—would do this by ensuring the definition is the same as the one applied to native title claimants. Labor won't even support an inquiry into this festering issue, refusing to acknowledge the distress of real Indigenous people over the frauds who falsely claim to be one of them. Labor will not let such an inconvenient truth get in the way of their deceptive campaign for the 'yes' vote.

One Nation has been at the forefront of the 'no' case, campaigning hard, while other parties sat on the fence for months. We're proud to stand for racial equality in Australia. We're proud to stand with Australians who understand our Constitution and system of government has been no barrier to effective democratic representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We are proud to stand against protecting the Aboriginal industry gravy train in our nation's founding document. We seek to leverage the education and employment opportunities which are bound in Australia to empower Indigenous people with the same agency and prosperity we can all enjoy. We just need to get the grifters in the Aboriginal industry out of the way so that these opportunities can be taken by those who really need them.

I speak to a lot of Aboriginal people as I've travelled this country far and wide. They don't want this. To get up and say the Uluru statement is supported by Aboriginals across the country is a lie—an absolute lie. Most of the Aboriginals in remote, rural and regional areas are sick and tired of being used as fodder for those who are pushing their own agenda. They see themselves as Australians and want to be treated as Australians equally. They're sick and tired of what you're trying to do to them. These people like Marcia Langton, Noel Pearson, the late Charlie Perkins, Paul Coe—the whole lot of them; the first Aboriginal lawyer who didn't represent one Aboriginal when they were in prison.

All these people have risen, and what have they done? They're on the gravy train to get to prominent positions and push their own agenda. The nepotism, the corruption that happens in these bodies and the land councils and everywhere else. The people who really need the help are screaming out. And you know what? They're coming to me because they're sick and tired of it. They want some truth and honesty. They want justice, and you turn a blind eye to this because you're listening to those ones that are there to look after themselves. Mark my words—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Fawcett ): Just a reminder to address your remarks through the chair.

Senator HANSON: One Nation's work on fraud with the assistance of ethical Indigenous leaders has already exposed strong evidence of corruption in this industry, and we have barely scratched the surface. This is real truth telling, and we will continue to do it in the face of Labor's lies and deception. We will never support racial inequality in our Constitution. We will support inclusion, not exclusion. All Australians have an opportunity to reject racial inequality. We will not divide the Australian people. We will unite the Australian people. One people, one nation, under one flag, the Australian flag.

talker.name: Fawcett, Sen David (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator FARRELL (South Australia—Minister for Trade and Tourism, Special Minister of State and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate) (20:08): I welcome this opportunity to speak to this important bill, the Constitutional Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023. We know that no community in Australia has suffered dispossession or disadvantage on the scale of Indigenous Australians. Now our chamber has before it the opportunity to be on the right side of history as we prepare to recognise Indigenous Australians through a voice to parliament.

Referenda are an integral part of our democracy. They allow Australians to amend our national birth certificate. Referenda allow society to reflect changes that are so significant we must alter our Constitution. This referendum will give Australians the chance to write a new chapter into our Constitution. Our new chapter will say:
In recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as the First Peoples of Australia:
(i) there shall be a body, to be called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice;

(ii) the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice may make representations to the Parliament and the Executive Government of the Commonwealth on matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples;

(iii) the Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws with respect to matters relating to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice, including its composition, functions, powers and procedures.

To pave the way for this referendum, earlier this year the parliament endorsed the changes to update the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. I had the great honour, with Senator Hume, of shepherding through that legislation to update the referendum laws so that voters can have a similar experience in this referendum as the experience they would expect of a modern federal election. The parliament updated that legislation to ensure that integrity and transparency measures that currently apply to federal elections will also apply to referenda. We introduced the first political donations scheme into the referenda so that amounts donated and spent over a disclosure threshold are reported. Importantly, we made sure that foreign donors are kept out of our democratic processes. I'm pleased to remind senators that, on the passing of that bill, it did not receive a single 'no' vote in this chamber.
Honourable senators: Hear, hear!

Senator FARRELL: Yes, hear, hear! I thank all senators for their support in those amendments. The bill before us now is required to hold a referendum to amend the Australian Constitution to recognise the first peoples of Australia in the constitution by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander voice. The referendum to enshrine a voice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the Constitution will be about two things: recognising and listening. It will be about recognising Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as the first peoples of Australia with 65,000 years of history and continuous connection to this land. It will be about listening to the voices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples when it comes to laws and policies that affect them.

As someone who grew up in a largely Anglo-Celtic community in Colonel Light Gardens in Adelaide, my experience of Indigenous culture and community as a child was limited. My experience and my memories are limited to watching and looking at lanky Tiwi Islander David Kantilla leading South Adelaide to victory in the 1964 SANFL Grand Final. For my generation, this limited understanding was wrongly normalised. I'm proud that this is no longer the case for my children and grandchildren, who have grown up with more understanding and more opportunities to experience this important part of our history and the story of our nation.
Australians will be asked a simple question at the referendum:
A Proposed Law: to alter the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice.
Do you approve this proposed alteration?

For many Australians, including my three daughters, Mary, Tess and Emily, this will be the first time that they've ever voted in a referendum. To be able to participate in making such an important and fundamental change must be taken very seriously by electors. I ask that they heed the invitation of Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and join their cause for recognition and a voice.

The journey to this point has been long and it's been challenging. I recognise the work of all First Nations people and the community leaders who have brought us to this point in history. Your work and efforts to drive this issue forward in our nation and put it on the agenda are now highly commended and applauded. I also want to take a moment to acknowledge those in this place who have spearheaded the issue: the Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon. Linda Burney; the Attorney-General, Mark Dreyfus; the Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Senator the Hon. Malarndirri McCarthy; the Special Envoy for Reconciliation and the Implementation of the Uluru Statement from the Heart, Senator Patrick Dodson; and the member for Lingiari, Marion Scrymgour.

Our government went to the Australian people at the 2022 federal election with a clear commitment to hold a referendum in this term of parliament. The Australian people elected our government to hold this referendum. Our nation should not stand still because of fear and doubt. The drafters of our Constitution had faith in our citizens. They gave us the tools to make sure that our founding document can be kept relevant and adapt to changing communities. They gave us the gift of a constitutional change through referenda. My plea to senators is not to fall victim to fearmongering. Don't let the unwillingness of some hold Australia back. This referendum is the best chance we have had to address the injustices of the past and create change that will deliver a better future. I for one look forward to an Australia in which, through the Voice, government can listen to communities and be better informed to deliver better laws, policies and outcomes than governments before. I commend the bill and urge senators to support the alteration so that we can move forward towards a fairer Australia in which the First Peoples of Australia are recognised and listened to.

Senator O'SULLIVAN (Western Australia—Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (20:15): I rise to speak on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023 bill. Australia has not changed its Constitution by referendum since 1977. You could argue that changing the Constitution is a big deal, which is why it is rarely changed in this country. It's important that all Australians get the opportunity to be able to have their say on this question that's going to be put before them. I respect the mandate that's been provided to the government to put this question to the Australian people. It was an election commitment that they made. What we're doing here today is to enable that question to be able to be put to the Australian people.

I'll be voting no in the upcoming referendum, and I'll lay out my reasons why throughout this contribution tonight, but I do respect the mandate the government have been given to be able to have this question put. I for one will be voting against this particular legislation not because I'm opposed to the question being put to the Australian people—I actually support the legislation—but to facilitate the 'no' pamphlet being put forward. I'm an authorised dissenter as part of the mechanism bill that's required, and so I'll be one of those that will be voting no to the particular legislation, but I just wanted to make it clear that I do support Australians being given the option to be able to have the question put to them by way of the referendum.

I want to state and outline: I am deeply committed to seeing the lives of Indigenous people improve in this country. It is heartbreaking to think of the disadvantage that is here at present in our country. I think of, particularly, the young people that look at the prospect of their lives and see it cut short by a decade or more. I think of Indigenous women, that are eight times more likely to end up in hospital due to domestic violence. There are lots of very confronting realities that Indigenous people face. As a non-Indigenous person, it's not a reality that I have to live through. It's not a reality that my family, thankfully, are facing. But I am deeply committed.

I've spent a big part of my career working to assist, empower and support Indigenous people to be able to make a difference in their own lives. I was part of a program called Generation One, which was an initiative to create employment opportunities for Indigenous people across Australia. Through that program, we established 29 VTECs, Vocational Training and Employment Centres, across Australia. These VTECs worked with jobseekers that Centrelink had essentially written off as having intractable barriers to employment; many, multiple and significant barriers. Some were as simple as just lacking a bit of confidence. Others were more serious, like drugs or alcohol, maybe unstable accommodation, or as simple as not having a driver's licence and not having the capacity to be able to get to a job. There were a whole myriad of issues that were involved in their lives. Through the VTEC program, with the 29 across the country, we saw literally tens of thousands of people take up work. I'm really proud of the work we were able to do through that because I know that it made a significant difference in the lives of these people.

One of the things we used to do for every person that graduated from this program was give them a fishing rod. Some of these programs are run in the middle of Australia where there was no lake, ocean or river to fish from, but it wasn't about them actually using it; it was the emblem that it represented. It's that old saying: if you give someone a fish, you feed them for a day; if you teach someone how to fish, you feed them for a lifetime. So every one of these graduates from the training programs that I was personally involved in delivering, was issued with a fishing rod because it is about empowering people to be able to make a difference for their own lives.

On the proposal before us, I've got no doubt about the intent and the well-meaning nature of it in terms of the people that invested a lot into its development, but there are some fundamental issues I've got with the Voice that I want to outline and that I believe won't go to addressing the challenges that are being faced by Indigenous people across this country. The proponents of the bill say that it's all about constitutional recognition, but the reality is it's much more than that. If the question was: should Indigenous people be recognised in the Constitution? I think there would be almost universal support for it across the country. But this proposal is much more than that. So on referendum day, I will be voting no for the following reasons.

To me, the Voice is a risk to our democracy. The Voice won't give Indigenous people, particularly in local communities, the voice that they desperately need. It will be isolated here in Canberra and it will be just another additional layer of bureaucracy. I believe that this proposal is wrong. Rather than being focused on local grassroots feedback from communities, it will be another Canberra based model. Recently, I undertook a trip to the Kimberley in northern WA—a place that I've visited many, many times. Certainly, for the work that I was doing through Generation One, I was up there all the time. I held several meetings across the region, in that week, meeting with communities that were dealing with significant issues, particularly in Fitzroy Crossing, which had, of course, just been through the flooding up there over January. You would think that, if there was a community that saw the Voice as the answer, that would be a community that would raise it with me. It's not to say that the Voice isn't supported in that community, but no-one actually raised it with me as being part of the solution to the challenges that are being faced.

It was the same in Kununurra where there are, sadly, significant youth crime issues. I was there for Anzac Day. The sun gets up a little earlier in Kununurra than it does in Perth because of where it's situated in the time zone. It was about four o'clock in the morning and I was on my way to Anzac Hill. I've got to say it was one of the most amazing Anzac Day dawn services I've ever been to. A boab tree is the cenotaph, and it was just the most magical and amazing experience being there. But on my way to that service at four o'clock in the morning there were crowds of kids in the middle of town, throwing stuff on the road and over cars as we were driving through. They weren't there because it was a public holiday that day. It's a regular occurrence. That's the dysfunction going on in that community. So you would think, if the Voice was the answer, I would hear it directly from people. I'm not a well-known person, and people wouldn't necessarily understand what my position is. I mean to say that they wouldn't necessarily be biased, or in any way timid to bring forward their ideas, because those who do know me know that I am someone who's deeply committed and compassionate about these issues. But nobody raised it.

I raised it with a number of people, particularly Indigenous people that I met with. I asked them if they support it. I'd say the response was pretty mixed. It was probably mostly in support of the Voice, in fairness. Nonetheless, there were still lots of people that actually didn't support it. For those that did support it I asked them why? They said, 'We want a seat at the table when decisions are being made.' I understand that, but in Fitzroy Crossing I had a discussion with a gentleman there who is a well-known person—I won't mention his name—who said to me that he believes we should have a seat at the table. I said: 'Hang on, in the first part of this conversation we were talking about some of the challenges in the community. You've said to me that even though you're part of the Shire of Derby/West Kimberley, you're sick of people in Derby speaking for Fitzroy Crossing. What do you think will happen when this national body is created and you have 24 or 30 people?'—or whatever the number will be—'We don't know what the number will be, because there's a significant lack of detail about proposals for the Voice.' He said that he recognised the challenge of that.

I wasn't there to try to convince him otherwise; he was supportive of the Voice. But the reality is that I don't believe the concerns on the ground are going to be met by this top-down approach. The proposal that we've put, that we actually took to the last election, was to have a grassroots model that empowered people in communities, that empowered people in Kununurra, in Fitzroy Crossing, in Laverton, in Leonora and in Perth to come up with the solutions that are necessary to address the issues in their communities.

In Kununurra, for example—and I've told you about the dysfunction of youth in that community—rather than having kids shipped all the way down to Perth to detention at Banksia Hill, which, obviously, has been in the news a lot lately, they have ideas to actually take kids out on country. They'll support them where they are; provide them with the support necessary and the justice reinvestment. These are the sorts of ideas that have come up and which ought to be supported.

Even those who oppose the Voice come into this place and, certainly on media or through other means, say things like: 'We already have 11 Indigenous members of parliament. They have a voice.' I think that's actually oversimplifying the issue and I think it's putting too much of a burden on our Indigenous members of parliament here in this place. I think it's up to each and every one of us, all 76 members of this place and the 151 members in the other place, to listen to the voices of those in their communities and respond to those needs. I think Indigenous people do have a voice, and it's us. It's us! It's each and every one of us. And if there isn't a response that's appropriate to the needs on the ground, then we have an issue of listening—not an issue of voice. What we need is a better response and a mechanism to be able to make that happen.

Some will say that that's the idea of the Voice. The biggest issue I have, putting all that to one side, is that this enshrines it within the Constitution. There are means and mechanisms to create a body that would be able to provide advice to government and provide advice at a local level—and even at a national level. But it doesn't need to be done by way of a constitutional amendment that divides Australians on the basis of race and which gives Australians of a particular race extra representation in an enshrined constitutional way. It's not how it should be, and it's not an Australia that I want to see. It's not an Australia that I believe says to any Australian, every single citizen—whether your ancestors have been here for thousands of years, or if you were born here or if you arrived recently and you've been sworn in as a new citizen at your local town hall last Thursday night—that you shouldn't be afforded the same rights. This proposal divides Australians on the basis of race.

To me, if the Voice is the answer then surely, surely, its success should be measured by its future redundancy? That's so that some day we'll be able to look back and say that it has fixed the issue. But I believe that by enshrining it in the Constitution it's actually saying to the generations, particularly to those young people who I spoke about before who are looking at the future of their lives, that this disparity which exists between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians must always exist. That's not a future that I want to see for Australia.

So I will be voting no in the referendum. I've put that out there and I've been encouraging people, those who are listening and following this debate, to consider doing the same. We should not divide Australians on the basis of race but we should do absolutely everything within our power—and we have the power; it's called the Australian parliament—to engage with and listen to the needs that are in the community and support our community with answers and solutions to issues that they know they can fix. This is why I commend to Australians to listen carefully to this debate and make an informed decision.

Senator WHISH-WILSON (Tasmania) (20:30): Every day the Senate meets, we acknowledge our First Nations people. We pay our respects to elders past, present and emerging on the land on which we meet. And every day here over the last 11 years, I've bowed my head, looked at my desk and wondered what's the use of words if we take no meaningful action to back them up. Is it paying our respects if after six years we still haven't acted on the generous invitation in the Uluru Statement from the Heart, enacting voice, treaty and truth? Is it paying our respects if parliament still hasn't acted on the many recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody or on the reports on the stolen generations or Closing the Gap?

I was privileged enough to be invited by the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to address the significant Invasion Day rally in Hobart this year. I made these points, and I put my hand on my heart and meant it when I said that I'm tired of our parliament paying its respects if it doesn't act on First Nations justice and that more than anything I wanted to say, when I've left this place, that I had done something—actually done something—and that I was part of collective political action to create a legacy that was meaningful to our First Nations people.

The opportunity for a First Nations Voice to Parliament is what is before us. It's the government's agenda, which they took to the last election. We couldn't change or alter that. I accept and strongly agree that on its own, without treaty and truth to follow, the Voice alone is not meaningful enough and won't achieve justice for our First Nations people. Seeing this legislation pass and a successful campaign on the Voice referendum and the full Uluru Statement from the Heart would make me proud, because right now I feel ashamed and frustrated by all the wasted years. So, the question before the Senate is simple: do you support a change to the Constitution to enshrine a voice to Parliament?

The Voice is about improving the lives of First Nations people in this country. It's about working with Aboriginal people. It's about white Australia not automatically making decisions on their behalf, as we have done since we invaded, colonised and dispossessed this country hundreds of years ago. It is long beyond time for our nation to accept the generous invitation in the Uluru Statement from the Heart from 2017. But are we, as a nation, generous enough to even listen and accept that Aboriginal people should have a say in the things that affect them? Surely, this is not too much to ask? Surely, we owe our First Nations people at least that? This is a chance to change. If the Australian public votes no to this referendum I fear the pathway for reconciliation and justice will be lost. If Australia votes no to the Voice referendum, I can't see the nation then voting for a treaty or, God forbid, a future government even putting it on their electoral agenda. My hope is that a successful Voice campaign will carry the nation along the treaty pathway, carrying the doubters, the undecided and the confused with us. I'm just not sure what other politically viable pathway forward exists.

This referendum is not just about our First Nations people; it's about all Australians. Contrary to what you've heard from the LNP in this debate, it is about uniting all of our country. So many of us acknowledge and recognise the wounds of white invasion and colonisation of this country. This hole in our hearts and our soul can begin healing by this nation adopting the full Uluru Statement from the Heart—voice, treaty and truth.

Why is this referendum so important? Our Constitution doesn't recognise our First Nations people, their 65,000 years of rich culture, history and attachment to this land—the land we all love so much. Many of us feel connected to our country. We've only been on this country for a couple of generations. Just imagine the connection to country felt by our First Nations people, who have lived, loved, fought, died, laughed and danced for 2,000 generations—not 2,000 years but 2,000 generations. Imagine what we as a nation could learn if we actually respected and recognised that tradition and cultural heritage. This referendum is an important step in that recognition. The Voice would be a permanent fixture in the Constitution, advising the parliament and executive government on important issues that impact First Nations people. This should help move the dial on so many unacceptable social justice outcomes.

What will the Voice do exactly? It will advise on requests from our Australian parliament on anything that is relevant to our First Nations people: education, early childhood education, domestic violence, housing, health, land use and heritage issues—just to name some. All these critical issues and many others will lend themselves to the Voice. The Uluru Statement from the Heart says that these reforms are necessarily sequential. It's voice first then treaty then truth. Why is the order of the sequence—voice, treaty, truth—important? A First Nations voice protected by the Constitution will mean we have the best opportunity for treaty-making and truth-telling to be done on equal terms. The Voice was always meant to be the forerunner to treaty and truth.

The Greens are committed to a treaty and truth-telling and have fought hard for the Uluru statement to be fully adopted, including by pushing the government on its $5.8 million commitment to commencing work on setting up the Makarrata Commission. We should right now be full steam ahead on preparing for a treaty as this referendum unfolds. Anything less could be seen as a betrayal of the Uluru statement.

I'd like to note that First Nations delegates on the final Voice to Parliament have not been decided yet. Delegates will be chosen by First Nations people at the local community level. There will be no government appointments. The base model, still to be finalised, proposes two members from each state, the Northern Territory, the ACT and the Torres Strait. A further five members would represent remote areas due to their unique needs. It is intended to be representative and inclusive, reflecting gender parity and youth. The final composition of delegates will be sensitive and a critical factor in the ultimate success of the Voice. I accept this.

Let me state what should be obvious to decent, thinking Australians. Our First Nations people shouldn't be used as a political football. This has been happening for too long. There has never been a successful referendum without bipartisan support in our nation's history, but this is the first referendum of the digital age. I feel sickened by the fact that the Liberal-National coalition are politicising and putting in jeopardy this important step towards justice and restoring the pride of our First Nations people. The Nationals opposed the Voice before they even saw the detail we have before parliament tonight, and we know the Nationals are the tail that wags the Liberal-National coalition dog. That says it all. But I also know that there are some in the Liberal-National coalition who have good hearts on this matter, and I hope they follow them.

We must campaign with every tool we have to see a successful referendum. Not a single one of us who supports this wants to wake up on a day when a referendum might fail and know that we didn't do enough. This is a once-in-a-generation vote, and I acknowledge it's been such a long road for so many people. I would like to acknowledge the hard work of my fellow Greens senator from Western Australia Dorinda Cox, a proud Noongar woman; previous senator Rachel Siewert, who did an incredible amount of work in this place on this issue; and many other Aboriginal members of the Greens who support Voice and the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Thank you to Minister Burney, Senator Pat Dodson and all other government First Nations MPs, who have carried the burden of this journey for many long years. Tonight I want to especially acknowledge the government working group on the Voice, those giants in the Aboriginal movement, remarkable Australians, people who have committed their entire lives to justice and reconciliation, to the advocacy of Aboriginal people: Marcia Langton, Megan Davis, Ken Wyatt, Tom Calma, Noel Pearson, Aunty Pat Anderson and Rodney Dillon—to name just a few.

I'd like to finish by acknowledging Mr Yunupingu, a giant for our nation. The Australian of the Year in 1978, he worked with 11 prime ministers. He was a founding member of the Referendum Council, set up in 2015, which ultimately led to the Uluru Statement from the Heart. He's not with us today but his presence can be felt strongly in Parliament House right now. Marcia Langton was quoted as once hearing him say, 'When you hear the truth, it burns.' Well, it burns for me, Madam Acting Deputy President. I believe in my heart that supporting the Voice and voting yes to this referendum is the right thing to do.

Speaking of Mr Yunupingu, the words from Paul Kelly's song 'From Little Things Big Things Grow' are front of my mind tonight. A successful referendum on the Voice may not equal reconciliation and justice for some First Nations people in this country, and I want to acknowledge tonight that not all Aboriginal people support the Voice. On its own, I agree, it doesn't represent the justice we all want for First Nations people, but my genuine hope is that this first step will give us the momentum we need to achieve treaty and truth and see the full Uluru Statement from the Heart embraced by this nation. The Greens are committed to that. Regardless of the referendum vote outcome, we won't stop fighting for First Nations justice, but it will be so much harder if the nation doesn't back this in.

In my remaining couple of minutes I want to acknowledge the palawa people from my home state of lutruwita/Tasmania. There are some fierce warriors for Aboriginal justice in Tasmania. I know that the history of Tasmania, attempted genocide, can't be denied. The frontier wars, the appalling actions taken against our First Nations people in Tasmania—those wounds run very deep. I know that, if they're listening to my speech tonight, many of them won't agree with me promoting the Voice, because they want treaty, they want real justice. But I just want to say tonight that whitefella politics is still pretty brutal, and it's still pretty harsh and pretty unfair, but we have before us now a pathway for actually achieving reconciliation, and we have to do everything we possibly can to convince everyone we know in Australia to vote yes in this referendum and give us the best possible chance we could have to get justice for our First Nations people, restore their pride and build a better future together.

Senator SHELDON (New South Wales) (20:44): I want to begin this speech in a manner that the Senate respectfully does each morning by acknowledging the traditional owners of the land we're meeting on, the Ngunnawal and Ngambri people of the Canberra area. I also acknowledge the Gadigal people of the Eora nation on whose land I live and work back home in Sydney. I pay my respects to their elders past, present and emerging.

I rise in support of the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023. If we set aside all of the gas-lighting and politicking of too many of those opposed to the Voice, the simple fact is that the Voice is about two things. It is about recognition of the 65,000 years of shared history and continuous connection to this land by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, and it is about listening—that is, listening to the Indigenous Australians on the policies and issues which impact their lives because we know listening to communities leads to better policies and better outcomes. That is all—that is what this constitutional amendment is all about: recognition and listening.

I want to be clear that I don't think Australia is a racist country. In fact, I say we are one of the world's great multicultural success stories. But to do what some have suggested and look past the shameful treatment of Indigenous people since the arrival of the First Fleet on our shores in 1788 would do us all a great disservice. It is important we recognise the devastating frontier wars, which resulted in the deaths of as much as 90 per cent of the Indigenous population in those areas and saw state sanctioned massacres until as recently as 1928, less than a century ago. It is also important to remember the Stolen Generations, the forced removal of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families, which affected as many as one in three Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and continued until as recently as the 1970s.
Of course, the disadvantage and discrimination faced by Indigenous Australians continues today. As the Uluru Statement from the Heart, authored by 250 First Nations leaders, says:

Proportionally, we are the most incarcerated people on the planet. We are not an innately criminal people. Our children are alienated from their families at unprecedented rates. This cannot be because we have no love for them. And our youth languish in detention in obscene numbers. They should be our hope for the future.
These dimensions of our crisis tell plainly the structural nature of our problem. This is the torment of our powerlessness.

When you read those words and you hear the anguish and trauma of so many First Nations people, I'm always struck by how easy it would be for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be resentful and to reject any notion of reconciliation. Instead, what we have seen is extraordinary courage and graciousness from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who as a direct result of colonisation have been robbed, murdered, enslaved, disenfranchised, kidnapped and incarcerated. But, after all of that—even after all of that—they have invited all Australians to walk together with them towards a brighter future through the Uluru Statement from the Heart and through voice, treaty and truth.

Of all the dishonest and disingenuous attacks on the Voice, the worst of all is the description of the Voice as 'the Prime Minister's Canberra voice'. It is really gross because the people making that claim know it is patently false. They know that the Voice did not come from this place. They know that the Voice is not a political undertaking. As Noel Pearson and Dr Shireen Morris said in their submission on the alteration:
The concept of a constitutionally guaranteed First Nations voice builds on decades of Indigenous advocacy for greater responsibility and self-determination in their affairs.
And to quote Tyronne Garstone, a Bardi man and Chief Executive Officer of the Kimberley Land Council:

Constitutional recognition through a voice to parliament is not a proposal for a 'Canberra voice', the latest untrue and disingenuous talking point. It is degrading to Indigenous peoples, and our aspirations to support the voice will only be for the so-called elites and academics. What message does this send to our young people? That they should not strive for excellence in their education or become a recognised expert because politicians in Canberra will use that achievement to cast doubt on their legitimacy as a voice for our people?
I say this: by calling it a 'Canberra voice', you're actually stealing away a powerful statement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders on self-determination.

On the subject of theft, it took until 2008 for the Australian government to apologise for abhorrent injustices inflicted upon the Stolen Generations, and even then some in the building chose to walk out and boycott that apology as a political stunt. That shame will follow those people for the rest of their time in this place, regardless of any belated and politically motivated mea culpas. I tend to judge people by their actions, not by press conference. When someone walks out on an apology to people stolen as children from their families, says refugees who are victims of rape are 'trying it on' and says Victorians are scared to go out to restaurants because of African gangs only to never mention the issue again after a state election—I don't need to reflect on the opposition leader's character, because his actions speak for themselves. But I do recognise that, historically, all sides of politics, at times, have been on the wrong side of history and, at others, have been on the right side of history. My party has, of course, gotten it wrong in the past. Labor's support for many years of the White Australia policy is one example of that. Despite the history of the now opposition leader, let's not forget that the Liberals are also the party of Neville Bonner and the party that delivered the 1967 referendum. The fact is that, throughout history, Labor and Liberal alike have demonstrated an ability to set politics aside and come together for the common national interest. The Voice is no different.

I note the courage and convictions of: the member for Berowra; the member for Bass; the member for Calare; Senator Bragg, with whom I disagree very strongly on many things but who has shown real integrity on this issue; the Tasmanian Premier; the former premier Dominic Perrottet; former minister Ken Wyatt; former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull; former Liberal leader John Hewson; and many others in the Liberal and National parties. I appreciate that some opposite legitimately disagree with the concept of the Voice, but what is truly disappointing is those who claim to be moderates who previously indicated support for the Voice and yet now are choosing their own personal political interests over an opportunity for real and lasting reconciliation. Those members and senators know who they are, and it is truly disappointing. As we know, since Federation, Australian governments of all political persuasions have made decisions for First Nations people but not with them. I think we can all recognise that the conditions facing Indigenous Australians represent collective failings of Australian governments going back to Federation. And so, as the Uluru statement calls for, we must return to the founding document of this federation, the Constitution.

The Constitution is a roadmap for our nation. It is not, as some have suggested, a place for exhaustive detail about the functions and administrative arrangements of the government and related entities. It never has been. I reinforce the words of my colleague Senator Pat Dodson, who said earlier this year:
The Parliament deals in detail. We do that every day of the week. That's why we have oppositions and arguments and committees and reviews etc. That's where detail is done.
Senator Dodson went on to say:
There are some out there who are pressing for more detail. They will never get enough ...

Senator Dodson's comments have been supported by a long list of constitutional lawyers, the High Court justices and other legal experts, as was canvassed in the inquiry into this alteration. I say it again: the Constitution is a mission statement for our nation. As the values of Australian people change, the Constitution must change with them. Senator Dodson said in his first speech in this place, 'At the time when the Australian Constitution was drafted, the only two express references to Indigenous Australians in the Constitution were section 127 and section 51, and both related to our exclusion—a situation that lingered in the constitutional landscape of this nation until the 1967 referendum.'
The Uluru statement says:
In 1967 we were counted, in 2017 we seek to be heard.

Now it's time for all Australians to collectively decide whether Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders will be heard. I note leaders of the major Australian religious groups—including the Catholic, Uniting and Anglican churches; the National Imams Council; the Executive Council of Australian Jewry; the Hindu Council; the national Sikh Council of Australia; and the peak body for Australian Buddhists—have all announced their support for the Voice. All of them. And to quote from their joint letter to this parliament:

The Voice is an invitation to move towards national healing, unity and reconciliation. It seeks to formalise in our Constitution a way by which First Nations' voices and concerns can be heard, and to establish a means for overcoming the devastating effects of social exclusion. This is an opportunity to unite Australians around a proposal that seeks to make life better for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I particularly encourage all Australians to listen to First Nations people's views on the Voice, and to block out the noise, the politicking and the gaslighting from some in this building who want to turn this referendum into something it is not.

This referendum is about two things: recognition and listening. And in that spirit, I dedicate the remainder of my time to support the voices of First Nations Australians and their views on the Voice. It goes without saying that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are not a monolith. There are a multitude of views on the Voice, although polling does show a large majority—over 80 per cent—of First Nations people support the Voice. Kishaya Delaney, a Wiradjuri woman from Orange, New South Wales, says:
I can see the ways in which laws impact Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across the country.
And the way in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people do not have any say on those laws.
I think it's about time that First Nations people were at the table before the laws were made, so we can ensure it's the best thing for our community.
And Aunty Ruth Dunn, from Dhanggati country in northern New South Wales, says:
We are the voice of our elders who have passed on and didn't have a voice at the time.
We need a Voice to represent our people and our culture and our nation.
Being First Nations people, we're the last to be heard, the last to be counted.
We don't want to be the last anymore; we want to be equal to all the other cultures in the world, and even to white Australians.
And lastly, to quote again from the Uluru Statement from the Heart:

We seek constitutional reforms to empower our people and take a rightful place in our own country. When we have power over our destiny our children will flourish. They will walk in two worlds and their culture will be a gift to their country.
We invite you to walk with us in a movement of the Australian people for a better future.

Senator HENDERSON (Victoria) (20:59): In the proposed referendum to establish a Voice to parliament and the executive, Australians will be given the very significant responsibility to decide the character of our government, the future of our constitutional settlement and the fate of our democratic system. In the book of our history there will be few chapters as significant as the one being written today. Like many Australians, I believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders should be recognised in our Constitution as the First Peoples and custodians of this land. However, the government's proposal to recognise Indigenous Australians in our Constitution through the establishment of an Indigenous voice to parliament and the executive is a very different proposition. It's a proposal which would give rise to a very substantial constitutional risk.

This proposal will append to our Constitution a new chapter—chapter 9—which will establish the Voice as a permanent fixture of our political and legal system. This proposal is not, as some have suggested, an organic development or merely a matter of completing the work of recognition begun by the 1967 referendum. This proposal will permanently graft onto our Constitution a body whose powers are unclear, whose members are unknown, whose remit is potentially unlimited and whose influence on the parliament, the government and every part of the executive will run unchecked. In this sense, the proposal before the Australian people is that they bind themselves under the authority of a constitutionally enshrined body whose members they will not elect and will not be able to hold accountable. To whom will the members of the Voice answer? To whom will they give an account of their actions? We have heard a number of vague proposals about First Nations people electing Voice members, but the government has resolutely refused to provide satisfactory detail about exactly how this will work.

We have heard a number of other vague statements about how constitutional recognition is an opportunity to acknowledge our history and come together for a more reconciled future, but the government has resolutely refused to explain why this more reconciled future depends on all of us voting yes to the Voice. Senator Dodson has said:
The moment the referendum is declared we will feel the shackles of the past fall from us.
But I say that to vote yes to this proposal is to exchange one set of shackles for another. I reflect on the words of Professor Marcia Langton, as reported in today's Australian. She said:
People who are opposing (the voice referendum) are saying we are destroying the fabric of their sacred Constitution. Yes, that's right, that's exactly what we're doing …
The Voice is Labor's voice. It is risky, unknown, divisive and permanent.

Make no mistake, this Voice will undermine our democracy by placing power in the hands of people we will not elect to influence government at all levels. We should not be distracted by the innocent-sounding idea that the Voice will merely make representations to the executive government of the Commonwealth. As the Prime Minister himself has said, only a 'brave government' would defy the Voice. The power to make representations to the executive government of the Commonwealth means that the Voice will extend itself into every facet of the government of this country—from the Governor-General to the Australian Taxation Office, from ASIO to Centrelink and the Australian Federal Police. The activity of the executive directly affects the lives of all Australians, whether they're young or old, rich or poor. The Voice will be able to make representations to every executive agency on any matter whatsoever, from migration decisions to sentencing regimes and welfare payments.

The Voice will be, for all intents and purposes, a fourth branch of government. It will be a branch of government that's unaccountable to the vast majority of Australians and it will be a branch of government exercising considerable power, untrammelled by the traditional checks and balances which have for many years provided Australians with the surety that political power in this country is exercised democratically. The successful balance between the three traditional branches of government is one we should guard very jealously. We have an executive that's accountable to the legislature, a legislature whose laws are interpreted by the judiciary and a judiciary whose limited powers and responsibilities are carefully set out in statutes and in the Constitution. Each element of this political trinity is accountable to the other two and ultimately to the Australian people. These traditional checks and balances are a hallmark of the Westminster system, which we have inherited from Great Britain. They have, for hundreds of years, been the steady safeguard against the exercise of tyrannical power by the executive, the legislature or the judiciary. We need only cast our minds back to the reign of terror or to the Russian revolution to see what happens when these checks and balances are obliterated in the madness of radical utopianism.

The framers of our Constitution were keen students of history; they knew this. Accordingly, they wove these checks and balances into the very fabric of our Constitution. The Constitution is not merely the founding document of our nation; it sits at the apex of our legal system. This means it matters very much what we put in the Constitution. Every word matters. This is why the High Court has spent over 100 years interpreting the Constitution. This is why, in their wisdom, Australians have only accepted eight proposals for constitutional change since Federation in 1901. The last time they did so was in 1977. One such occasion was the 1967 referendum, and we should be proud that over 90 per cent of the nation voted in favour of those amendments.

Nevertheless, there is no doubt that Australians are constitutional conservatives. We do not like having radical constitutional amendments foisted upon us, but we are also not reactionaries. It is part of the genius of our nation that we have found a way to adapt our existing laws over time to achieve great social reforms without significantly altering the constitutional settlement upon which those reforms are built. But the government is not satisfied with this. The government wants to give some Indigenous Australians special rights which other Australians, including the vast majority of Indigenous Australians, do not have. Practically speaking, the Voice will allow a small group of Indigenous Australians to influence government decision-making to an extent unprecedented in our nation's history.

Of course, the great irony is that our parliament is comprised of some incredible Indigenous voices, voices such as Senator Nampijinpa Price and Senator Liddle, to whom the Albanese government failed to listen over the destructive lifting of alcohol bans in the Northern Territory, until the government was shamed into action when the violence and dysfunction in a number of communities rapidly escalated.

I'm also deeply concerned that, throughout all of this debate, we have not heard any evidence at the how the Voice will make a difference on the ground in local communities and remote settlements where it really matters. Not one Voice proponent has spoke spoken of the need for the Albanese government to fund the boarding facilities at the Yipiringa School in Alice Springs so that the children caught in a web of dysfunction and family violence, and the children who are forced to travel on a bus for up to three hours a day, can attend school safely and securely. Not one proponent of the Voice has spoken about the need to provide urgent medical and dental care to the children living in the town camps outside Alice Springs, children who are in need of basic care that so many Australians take for granted. These are my observations from just one trip recently to Alice Springs, where I joined Senator Nampijinpa Price to lobby the government to match the coalition's commitment to the Yipurinya School, funding which has still not delivered.

The local regional Indigenous voices are the voices which matter, not Labor's voice. Even eminent Indigenous leader Nick Gooda has raised deep concerns that the Albanese government's decision to extend the Voice to the executive is serious overreach and has urged compromise. The Voice's constitutional status will mean that it will be able to challenge government decisions on a potentially unlimited range of matters if it believes its representations were not heeded. As former High Court Justice Ian Callinan, AC KC said, this could bring on 'a decade of constitutional and administrative law litigation …' Instead of setting up a series of local and regional voices which can respond effectively to real problems affecting Indigenous Australians, the government is proposing that another layer of bureaucracy be added to our already bloated system.

The concerns that I raise in relation to the reach of the Voice are not exaggerated concerns. They are reflected in the views of many eminent lawyers, judges and other legal experts who have strongly cautioned against assuming the High Court will not imply a duty for the executive to consult the Voice on matters which relate to Indigenous Australians. Indeed, an implied duty to consult the Voice on any proposed decision—which former High Court Judge Robert French conceded 'would really make government unworkable' and said, 'I don't think the High Court is in that business'—cannot be ruled out. A future High Court may well decide to imply this right. Former High Court Judge Ian Callinan said: 'It would be imprudent to underestimate the capacity of any future High Court for ingenuity or originality.' It is an irony that so many of the proponents of the Voice, well intentioned and highly regarded as they are, should be echoing the language so often and infamously used by the late Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen to reports seeking information about government when he said, 'Don't you worry about that.'

For such a significant moment in our constitutional history, the government's approach has been embarrassingly poor, and Australians know it. It has rushed the consideration of the Voice proposal through the parliament's joint select committee in a matter of weeks. It has repeatedly refused to release all advice given to it by the Solicitor-General in relation to the Voice. The Albanese government has denied the Australian people the benefit of having the Voice proposal considered properly by a constitutional convention, and it has engaged in a concerted campaign of secrecy in relation to the composition, functions, powers and procedures of the Voice. Clearly the government does not trust the Australian people to make an informed choice about this proposal, an attitude which is as sinister as it is condescending.

Like my colleagues in the Liberal Party, I will not stand opposed to this bill. Like them, I'm committed to maintaining the democratic right of all Australians to vote on the way they are governed—a right this Voice proposal will undermine forever. At the referendum, Australian will make one of the most important decisions in our nation's history. To all Australians I say: stand up. Stand up and be counted. As Churchill said:
There is only one duty, only one safe course, and that is to try to be right and not to fear to do or say what you believe to be right.

Stand up without fear and make your voice heard. I say: vote no to protect our democracy. Vote no to protect our Constitution. Vote no to protect our democratic rights. I will be voting no to this proposed Voice, and I urge all Australians to do the same.

Senator ALLMAN-PAYNE (Queensland) (21:13): I begin this evening by acknowledging that we are meeting on the sovereign and unceded lands of the Ngunnawal and Ngambri peoples. I also wish to acknowledge the Byellee, Gooreng Gooreng, Gurang and Taribelang Bunda peoples who are the traditional custodians of the land on which I live and work in Central Queensland. I would also like to acknowledge the First Nations senators in the chamber tonight, Senators McCarthy and Stewart.

I am humbled by the gracious invitation extended to all Australians in the Uluru Statement from the Heart by the First Nations people of this country. I support this bill, the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023, and I will be voting yes in the referendum. We must progress all elements of the Uluru statement: truth, treaty and voice.

During my time as a teacher, I spent years living and working on country with the communities of Cape York and the Torres Strait. Here I came face to face with the effects of colonisation and systemic racism on First Nations peoples. I came to fully appreciate the profound impacts that government policy and decision-making has on people's lives. For too long, First Nations voices have been ignored. Whilst living and working on Cape York, I witnessed firsthand how governments play lip service to consulting with First Nations communities. Prior to the introduction of designated dry communities in Queensland, I was asked by local community members to attend a so-called community consultation with the state government. Members of the community were already seated around the table when the minister and their staff rolled in, but the so-called consultation began with the minister stating that there would be no consultation and that the government would be designating the community a dry community. I remember being both shocked and disgusted by the complete disregard for that community's wishes, but what I now know is that for First Nations people this was just one more indignity imposed upon them by a government that was never interested in giving them a say in the first place.

As a teacher, I know that First Nations kids are overwhelmingly left out or left behind by our education system, an education system that doesn't fully fund its schools, robbing its students, especially First Nations students, of their future. During my time working on the cape, I worked in a school where the classrooms flooded every time the rains came—and those who've lived on the cape would know that it rains a lot. The library was small and under-resourced, and teachers bought their own tins of paint to paint the classrooms. My parents, both former teachers, were so shocked at the condition of the school when they visited that they were prompted to write to the education minister expressing their concerns, but the minister's response was to send a 'please explain' to our school principal to respond to my parents.

For too long, First Nations people have not been listened to and they haven't been heard, but the Voice to Parliament is just one part of the Uluru Statement from the Heart, and this is not the end of the journey towards justice for First Nations people in this country. We cannot disentangle the violence of colonisation from the present. This history has guided the development of modern Australia. It is embedded in our institutions, it is embedded in our democracy and it has been embedded in our culture. Disregarding history only fixes this structure of violence into the future. Truth and treaty are how we move forward together. The Greens are fighting and will continue to fight for real and meaningful progress on truth and treaty.
