Treaty was promised to people in this country in the 1980s. We are finally seeing progress on treaties around Australia in different states, but we must not continue to delay the process at the federal level.

The Prime Minister and the government must implement the Uluru statement in full as they have promised. The October 2020 budget committed $5.8 million to the Makarrata Commission. This is welcome, but we are yet to see real action on this. This needs to change. Only when we have the effective implementation of all three elements of the Uluru Statement from the Heart will we see progress on closing the gap, on ending racial discrimination and on achieving self-determination for Australia's First Nations people. Constitutional change alone won't change the material lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

For decades, governments have ignored the voices of First Nations people and the recommendations of numerous inquiries and royal commissions. First Nations people continue to experience poor health and education outcomes, lower life expectancy, shocking incarceration rates and institutional violence. The Voice referendum is an opportunity for all Australians to show solidarity with the First Nations people of this country and to work towards true equality and healing.

Senator BILYK (Tasmania) (21:19): I rise this evening to speak on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023, and I'd like to start by stating that I support Voice, treaty and truth as outlined in the Uluru Statement from the Heart. I would also like to acknowledge and thank Minister Linda Burney, Senator Malarndirri McCarthy and Senator Patrick Dodson for all their hard work over many, many years in working towards making this important constitutional change possible.

I stand before you today to advocate for a monumental step towards reconciliation, justice and unity in our great nation. This is a crucial opportunity for Australia, which holds the promise of transforming our nation's journey towards reconciliation, equality and true democratic representation. For over 60,000 years, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have occupied this great land of ours, proudly representing the oldest continuous living culture in human history. Yet, despite this unbroken connection with country, a unique and deeply spiritual relationship with Australia's land, waters and skies since time immemorial, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are still yet to be recognised in our Constitution.

The Indigenous Voice to Parliament is a testament to the Albanese government's commitment to reconciliation, a commitment that requires us to acknowledge and address the profound disadvantages and systemic inequities faced by Indigenous Australians. For too long, their voices have been silenced, their perspectives ignored and their rights marginalised. It's time for us as a federal parliament to listen and act in accordance with the principles of justice, self-determination and respect.

The Uluru Statement from the Heart was the culmination of years of discussion, consultation, activism and hard work by so many people, both Indigenous and non-Indigenous. At its heart is an invitation to all Australian people to walk together as one, through the practical establishment of a First Nations Voice in the Australian Constitution. Australia now has an opportunity to vote for meaningful change in the form of constitutional recognition that is both practical and substantive. This vote is an opportunity for us all to stand as one, offering a clear pathway forward to healing the past injustices, for a more inclusive, unified and compassionate Australia.

If successful, the referendum will result in four lines being inserted into the Constitution. These lines will finally recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as Australia's first peoples, rectifying hundreds of years of explicit exclusion from the Constitution. It's worth highlighting that, despite 60,000 years as the custodians of this land, First Nations people were never afforded any representation in the constitutional convention leading to Federation. It would be difficult to argue that this oversight represents anything other than a gross injustice that must be addressed through constitutional change.

The establishment of a permanent Voice to Parliament represents the constitutional recognition Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders called for in the Uluru statement. Throughout the debate on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023, it's disappointing that there has been considerable misinformation and fearmongering put forward by those opposed to this constitutional change. We have heard claims by some critics that the Indigenous Voice to Parliament is redundant or unnecessary. But we must recognise the unique challenges faced by Indigenous communities. Indeed, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people continue to be significantly disadvantaged today, and the statistics provide grim evidence of this. To name but a few examples, we need only look at an almost nine-year gap in life expectancy, gaps in infant mortality and educational attainment and the fact that, despite representing only approximately three per cent of the overall population of Australia, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders make up 32 per cent of all prisoners. This gives First Nations people the unenviable distinction of being the most incarcerated people in the world.

Although these are only a few examples of the profound disadvantages faced by Indigenous peoples, clearly something is not right. Previous attempts to address the disadvantage faced by First Nations people have simply not worked. While well intentioned, most government programs and interventions have failed to achieve their goals of improving the outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Year after year, the Closing the gap report highlights this sad failure. In the latest report from the Productivity Commission, only four of the 19 Closing the Gap targets are on track. Of most concern, the data shows that the figures for some key indicators have become worse. The rate of incarceration among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders has increased, as has the rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children in out-of-home care. Both groups continue to be significantly overrepresented. More of the same will simply not work.

We therefore require tailored solutions—specifically, a means by which First Nations people can have greater influence on their own destiny. By establishing an efficient channel through which Indigenous Australians can contribute to policy development, we're acknowledging the lived experiences and deep cultural knowledge that not only address the inequalities but also enrich our national fabric. This is an opportunity to tap into their wisdom, learn from their history and chart a course towards a more just and prosperous future. Furthermore, this bill builds upon the principles of self-determination and empowerment that underpin the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, a document to which Australia is a signatory. It demonstrates our commitment to honouring the rights, aspirations and unique cultural heritage of Indigenous Australians. By providing a formal mechanism for their voices to be heard and respected, we reaffirm our commitment to human rights and equal representation.

Now, we've heard from critics that this change to the Constitution would require the executive government to consider the Voice's representations or consult the Voice on every decision and that this would lead to protracted High Court litigation. Some have claimed that it may essentially bring government to a halt, with every decision, from submarines to parking tickets, requiring consultation with and approval by the Voice on all government matters. That's absolute rubbish. It's pure scaremongering. It's not consistent with the overwhelming consensus of constitutional experts, including the Solicitor-General Stephen Donaghue KC, who has stated that the proposed section 129 would not pose any threat to Australia's system of government.

It is essential to note the Indigenous Voice to Parliament is not intended to supplant or undermine existing democratic institutions. On the contrary, it complements our democratic system by bringing in diverse perspectives that have long been excluded from decision-making processes. It enriches our democracy by strengthening the checks and balances necessary for robust governance. The Voice will provide essential advice, contributing to better informed policy discussions and more effective outcomes for all Australians. To quote the Solicitor-General:
… s 129 is not just compatible with the system of representative and responsible government prescribed by the Constitution, but an enhancement of that system.

It's not just the Solicitor-General who holds this opinion. This sentiment is shared by legal experts, including former Chief Justice French, former Justice Hayne and the leading legal academic on constitutional matters, Professor Twomey, among others.

Another misconception bandied about by those opposed, most notably the Leader of the Opposition, is that if this referendum were to be successful it would somehow introduce race into the Constitution. That's completely absurd. The unfortunate and very sad reality is that race has played a significant part in many government decisions and will continue to do so without the recognition and representation that this constitutional amendment will bring. We needn't look too hard to find evidence of race based government decisions.

The stolen generation is just one shameful and deeply hurtful example of this. The Aborigines Protection Act 1909 legislated the lawful removal of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families so they could be assimilated into white society. Cut off from their families, country, language and culture, they were often treated with cruelty, which caused suffering and indignity not just for the stolen children but for all First Nations peoples. This is an unbelievably deep and painful scar on our history, one that all Australians must acknowledge was based purely on racially motivated government policy. Would this have happened if First Nations people had been recognised in the Constitution in the first place? Would this have happened if there had been some consultative approach by the government with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community representatives and elders?

These are race based inequalities that the proposed alteration to the Constitution seeks to address. It would finally recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples not as a race but as the first peoples of Australia. This is what the bill does. This is what the Voice would do. This is also the opinion of the esteemed former Chief Justice of the High Court, Robert French, who stated that the proposed constitutional alteration contained in the bill would represent:
… a significant shift away from the existing race based legislative power that the Commonwealth has with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people …

Such steps are vital to the healing process, not just for First Nations people but for all Australians. Anyone suggesting that this amendment would introduce race into the Constitution is either completely ignorant of our past or willingly choosing to turn a blind eye to the pain that's been inflicted on First Nations people by government legislation, primarily due to the absence of constitutional recognition. Shame on the Leader of the Opposition for even suggesting this.

It's also been claimed by the 'no' group that this proposal will cause division. How could it be that an amendment to the Constitution, which seeks to rightfully acknowledge Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as First Nations peoples of Australia, is somehow divisive? What are people afraid of? The suggestion is that the Voice will create two classes of Australians and that it will somehow give Indigenous Australians a place of privilege. I would encourage those people to visit Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, across the hundreds of communities throughout Australia, and really listen to their stories. By doing so, you will understand that this is not about conferring privilege but about addressing injustices, both past and present. It is about a fairer and more inclusive system of government for all Australians, particularly for those who have been ignored, abused and marginalised for so long. Those suggesting that the Voice to Parliament would create division amongst Australians are, in fact, seeking only to perpetuate the division that has already existed for a very long time.

In summation, the Indigenous Voice to Parliament presents an opportunity to address the appalling disparities faced by Indigenous Australians. As I stated, despite being the custodians of this land for thousands of years, they continue to suffer disproportionately from systemic disadvantage, including poor health outcomes, lower education levels and higher incarceration rates. This referendum offers a chance to bridge these gaps and foster real change. Inclusivity and reconciliation should not be seen as a threat to our national identity or values. Rather, they are strengths that will define us as a compassionate and progressive nation. By empowering Indigenous Australians to have a genuine say in the decisions that affect their lives, we are embracing the principles of fairness, justice and self-determination. We're acknowledging the fundamental truth that every Australian, regardless of their background, deserves an equal opportunity to thrive. To those who may harbour doubts or fears, I encourage you to look beyond the misconceptions and listen to the stories of Indigenous Australians, engage in genuine dialogue and seek to understand the historic injustices that have shaped the reality. This referendum is not just about policy. It's about empathy, compassion and healing the wounds of the past.

In conclusion, we have a unique chance to shape the future of our nation for the better and, as you may have gathered, I will be voting yes. By voting yes to the referendum on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament, I believe we are taking a significant step towards reconciliation and forging a new chapter in our shared history. Let's not miss this opportunity to create a more inclusive, equal and compassionate Australia, where the voices of all its people are valued and respected. Vote yes for unity, justice and a brighter future for all.

Senator SCARR (Queensland—Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (21:33): Acting Deputy President O'Sullivan, at the outset, I congratulate you on your contribution to this debate on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023. I thought you gave an outstanding speech. It was heartfelt, and the work you've done in remote and regional Aboriginal communities provides a strong sense of integrity to the arguments which you put. It was a privilege to be in the chamber when you gave that speech.

On of my most cherished possessions is an Aboriginal carving that was given to my grandfather when he was only four years old. My grandfather grew up in northern New South Wales at a time when there was great segregation between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and white Australians. This Aboriginal carving was given to my grandfather by the father of a little Aboriginal boy he used to play with on the farm. The father used to come to the farm with his son, and the two little boys used to play together. The Aboriginal father of that little boy was so moved by the fact that his son and my grandfather could play together—common humanity, playing together, regardless of race—that he gifted my grandfather this beautiful Aboriginal carving, which is in my parliamentary office today. It was something which my grandfather always cherished.

That represents the Australia I want to live in. That's the Australia I believe in—where we are together. I fear that the insertion of a new chapter in our Constitution which is different from all the other chapters in our Constitution is a departure from that fundamental principle that we should be together. If you look at our Constitution, there's a chapter on the House of Representatives, a chapter on the Senate, a chapter on executive government and a chapter on courts. Each and every one of those institutions is open to full participation by all Australians, regardless of their ethnicity, regardless of their race and regardless of when they became Australian citizens. Everyone is equal in each and every one of those institutions. Now we have before us the proposition to insert a new chapter into our Constitution which is something fundamentally different. I simply cannot support it.

One of the reasons why I will, in addition to not supporting the referendum question, be campaigning against it is the courage and the example which has been shown by people such as Senator Nampijinpa Price, my good friend and colleague Senator Liddle and people of the stature of Warren Mundine. I heard Warren Mundine give an interview recently where he referred to the fact that he'd been called an Uncle Tom by members of his community or members of the Australian community who disagreed with his position on the Voice. It brought into my memory one of my heroes, Neville Bonner, the first Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person to be elected to this parliament under that chapter of the Constitution establishing a Senate open to all Australians. Neville Bonner suffered the same indignity and the same insults for being his own person and standing up for his own beliefs.
Back in 2003, I made a submission to the Australian Electoral Commission that there should be a federal seat named after Neville Bonner. In that submission I wrote this:

Neville had every right to be bitter, angry and disillusioned with his country, but instead of being eaten up by such justified emotions, he rose above it and sought and attained elected office whilst maintaining his grace and dignity at all times. Has any Australian who has obtained a seat in the Senate since Federation achieved as much simply by being elected?

If I could give up my place in the Senate for this speech, if it were possible for me to leave this chamber and for Neville Bonner to take my place and make this contribution, I would surely do it. I must say before I made my contribution in the party room on this debate I went back and watched some of Neville Bonner's speeches to try and discern what he would make of all this. I would so dearly love for him to make a contribution to this debate at this time, but it's simply not possible.

My first objection is one of deep principle. I believe that every single institution established by our Constitution should be open to equal participation by every single Australian, regardless of race, ethnicity, sex, gender or religion, whether they became an Australian citizen last week or whether they're a descendant of the longest continuing culture in the world's history. That is my view, and it is one of principle.

My second deep concern with respect to a constitutionally-enshrined Voice is whether or not it will actually reflect the diversity of opinions amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. As I've sat in this place—and I've sat in this place for four years—I've heard the wonderful contributions of senators from across the chamber, including from our senators of Aboriginal heritage, including Senator McCarthy. I've listened to Senator McCarthy, Senator Dodson, Senator Stewart, Senator Cox, Senator Thorpe, my own colleague Senator Nampijinpa Price and Senator Liddle. They all have different perspectives, different philosophies, different ideas. How could they possibly be reflected in one institution called 'the Voice'? There are many voices, many perspectives, many philosophies, and there is absolutely no detail provided as to how that diversity of opinion would be reflected through the institution which is proposed.

What do we have in the context of detail? We have a bill of 303 words. That's it—303 words, in relation to making a radical constitutional change. That is all the Australian government is giving the people of Australia to assess, in the course of this debate—303 words.

In that context, we have had evidence from very eminent lawyers who have raised deep concerns with respect to the risks associated with a constitutionally-enshrined Voice to Parliament and to the executive government. In this respect, I note at the outset that the Langton-Calma report, the Indigenous Voice Co-design Process, originally said, in section 2.9:
The design also reflects the need to respect parliamentary sovereignty and avoid causing unintended consequences. As a result, all elements would be non-justiciable …
What happened to that commitment—that 'all elements would be non-justiciable'? Rejected. Abandoned.

In the Liberal members' dissenting report, in the Advisory report on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023, they raise a number of concerns. And I commend Keith Wolahan MP with respect to his contribution to this debate. Let it be known, let it be reflected on: six weeks, they had, to prepare this report with respect to a constitutional change—six weeks. The risks they raised are obvious ones. If you have a constitutional right to make representations, surely the corollary of that must necessarily be the parliament, executive government, has a duty to, at the very least, consult and consider. It necessarily follows. How can it not follow?

There are eminent lawyers who have made those representations in the course of this consideration and debate. The first I'd like to refer to is one of the titans of the legal world, in terms of constitutional law, who passed away on 15 May 2023: Mr David Jackson KC, of my home state of Queensland. Mr Jackson served as a Federal Court judge. He was involved in hundreds of constitutional cases and renowned in the legal community as one of Australia's leading constitutional experts. What did he say about the Voice? The first observation he made, in paragraph 18 of his submission to the committee, was that the power already existed. As he said:
The short fact is there is no reason at all why the Parliament cannot now legislate to establish a body which has features similar to those proposed for the Voice in proposed s 129.
There's nothing stopping it—nothing at all. Secondly, as he said at paragraphs 23 and 24:
There is also a second aspect, albeit having some relationship to the first.
The inclusion of the proposed s 129 would mean that we become a nation where, whenever we or our ancestors first came to this country, we are not all equal.

That is the question of equal civic rights. Those were the two points made by David Jackson. Those point were also supported by Ian Callinan, another eminent legal figure from my home state of Queensland, who talked about the context of legal action being taken around that duty to consider and duty to consult.

If people think this is made up—the term used earlier in the debate was 'gaslighting', as if this is misinformation—I refer people to the case of Love v Commonwealth of Australia and Thoms v Commonwealth of Australia. All you need to do is read the first paragraph. You do not have to be a legal scholar to understand the legal risks associated with the model that's proposed here. In the first paragraph, Her Honour Susan Kiefel, Chief Justice, said that, in this case where the plaintiffs were arguing that, as non-citizen people who had been resident in this country and had the opportunity to become residents but chose not to:

The plaintiffs argue that the power should be read so as not to apply to a person who is not a citizen of Australia, who is a citizen of a foreign country and is not naturalised as an Australian citizen, but who is an Aboriginal person.

That was the argument: that the Commonwealth did not have the power with respect to deportation of an Aboriginal person even if they were not born in in this country and were not a citizen of this country. This is what Her Honour said in the first paragraph:
… the plaintiffs contend that s 51(xix) is subject to an unexpressed limitation or exception.

Now, Her honour was not prepared to find such an limitation or exception. Neither was Justice Patrick Keane, from my state of Queensland. Neither was Justice Gageler, ex-Solicitor-General of Australia. But the other four High Court judges were. They found an unexpressed limitation or exception existed in our Constitution. Something which had not been identified for over 100 years was read into the Constitution, and that is the legal risk. It is heightened by the fact that there have been a number of proposals to address this risk and they have all been rejected. Why? Why are these proposals being rejected?

The first, that there should actually be a qualification to subsection (3) of the proposed amendment so that the subject of legal review would be the subject of this parliament to determine, was rejected. The second, that the second limb, subsection (2) of the proposed referendum, was unnecessary and could be omitted, was rejected. Father Frank Brennan proposed a change such that representation should only be able to be made to ministers as opposed to the rest of executive government, and that was rejected. All of those qualifications were rejected. Why? Why were those proposals rejected? That is the legal risk associated with this referendum.

When you combine that legal risk with the fact that they have only been eight referenda passed in Australia's constitutional history and none of them have been reversed, you will understand why there is a considerable proportion of this country who are already indicating that they will be voting 'no'. There is a fundamental difference from the referendum in 1967, and that is one of the reasons why: the lack of detail, the legal risk and the permanency. Those who are putting forward this model have refused at every juncture to compromise with respect to the wording, and I deeply fear that there is a tragedy unfolding in Australia this year. It is a great tragedy.

Senator McKIM (Tasmania—Australian Greens Whip) (21:48): I rise to speak on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023 tonight as a Tasmanian, as an Australian and as a Green who is committed to truth, treaty and justice for First Nations people. We're having this debate more than 200 years after this land was stolen from the people who lived here, the people who were its inhabitants and its stewards. It was stolen on the basis of the lie of terra nullius, the lie that there were no humans on this land when the Europeans arrived when in fact there were many. There were many who lived here, loved here and learned here whose ancestors had done so for countless generations. What followed that lie and that dispossession was more than 200 years of violence, of colonialism and of systemic racism, and it is an utter tragedy that those travesties are ongoing today. Those facts—and they are facts—now require from all of us an unwavering commitment to truth-telling, to genuine listening, to tangible action and, ultimately, to treaty. As a Tasmanian, I particularly acknowledge the Palawa Pakana people of lutruwita truwana Tasmania, made up of so many proud nations and proud people who are strong in their culture and defiant in their identity today. Their collective voice is strong and clear, and it calls us all to justice. It calls us to truth, it calls us to treaty and it calls us to return lands and waters to them—those lands and waters we stole from them.

I acknowledge the attempted genocide that occurred in lutruwita truwana Tasmania. That attempted genocide saw the colonial government and early settlers first starve out and then brutally hunt down the first Tasmanians. It saw them steal and rape their women. It saw them take their land unjustly, and it saw them ultimately banish many of the first Tasmanians to Wybalenna on Flinders Island, all the while lying to them in the most barefaced of ways in the name of the Crown. I acknowledge the fierce and wily Aboriginal warriors who defiantly and bravely resisted those deprivations from the early European settlers—those warrior men and women who fought bravely to defend their homes, their children and their lands from the brutality of the European invaders. I pay tribute today to their courage, their bravery and their spirits. Those spirits endure in the Palawa Pakana people in lutruwita truwana Tasmania, and that spirit will endure no matter what we decide in this place and no matter how Australians vote at a referendum. That spirit will endure—proud, fierce, ongoing.

There has been a lot said and done about the words in the question that Australians will answer in the referendum, and that's fair enough. These are weighty matters, but I want people to think about a much more simple and, I think, profound question than the one we will be asked, and that is this: do we want to start to heal the gaping wound at the heart of our country or do we want to make it worse? There is a gaping wound in our country's spirit, and that wound is caused by those facts that I referred to earlier, and many others—the racism, the theft of children, the theft of lands, the brutality, the colonialism and the violence that is ongoing today. There is a gaping wound in the heart of our country, and what we have got before us tonight and what Australians I trust will have before them later this year is a chance to start to heal that wound. That is fundamentally the choice that will be before us, and it is deeply important that as a country we choose wisely. This will be a moment in history, and it's critical that we seize the moment.

The Voice may not be a massive step towards truth and treaty, although it may yet turn out to be a significant step towards those things, and I genuinely hope that that is how it does turn out. But a truth I hold as self-evident is that for the Voice to fail at this moment in history would set back for decades the healing that our country so urgently needs.

I know that there are some First Nations folks who don't support the Voice, including in my home state of Tasmania—some proud, fierce Aboriginal leaders: aunties, uncles and young activists who I respect deeply for their courage and sincerity. I understand why they hold their views, and I respect them. I'm not surprised that some First Nations folks have differing opinions from others about the way forward. Of course they do. It's not as if we whitefellas haven't had some pretty significant differences of opinion between us throughout our history.

There are, of course, many First Nations folks who do support the Voice, who deeply, passionately believe in the Voice, and who have worked tirelessly and are working tirelessly today—and I acknowledge Senator McCarthy, who is in the chamber as I speak—to make Voice a reality. We are all indebted to all of those people. I acknowledge how they've put all of themselves into this, and I offer them my thanks and deep appreciation for everything that they've done. I genuinely hope that the creation of a Voice will come to be seen as an act of some generosity, a small counterbalance to the mass of meanness and viciousness to which First Nations people in this country have been subjected over the last couple of centuries and more.

I deeply feel that Voice alone is not the answer, but it is my sincere hope that it will be a significant step on a journey that will take us through a truth-telling process and ultimately take us to a treaty. Until that journey is over and until there is a treaty or treaties with First Nations in Australia, we will have monumental unfinished business in this country. I genuinely hope, and I do genuinely believe, that Voice will step us on the pathway to that destination. I commend this legislation to the Senate, and with all my heart I urge every Australian to vote yes for Voice when they get the chance. Honestly, I feel that if the referendum fails it would break the heart of our country, and I know most certainly it would break mine.

Senator PRATT (Western Australia—Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (21:57): As we speak on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023, thousands of Australians day by day are getting organised to build support to amend our Constitution to recognise First Nations people and create a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament and government for our nation. Indigenous and non-Indigenous people are working together to do this. By working together, we continue to change our nation and strengthen who we all are. The very practical act of the work that is going on, as part of this campaign and this debate and the organising, is part of what is changing that fabric of our nation, because when we elevate dialogue, culture and engagement with First Nations people we are no longer just a nation built from colonisation and migration; we're a nation with a heart, a heart that shines proudly in all of us, a heart that has been beating for at least 60,000 years. Millions of Australians are ready for this change because it speaks to who they want to be as a nation.

So, in the context of this bill, it carries great hopes. But I also want to just deliberate on some of the facts about it. In its form it's constitutionally sound and it is deliverable by this parliament. It's fit for purpose for another 100 or 200 years or more into the future, and it's consistent with the form and function of how we work here.

When people consider the issues before them when they vote on this bill, and at a referendum later this year, it's important to be able to debunk some of the arguments that come from those opposed to constitutional change. 'No, because there's no detail'—sounds like a good argument? Well, no, it's not. Our Constitution doesn't have the details in it. It's a place for enshrined principles. The power of the Commonwealth to govern corporations is but one line in our Constitution, and yet the Corporations Act is thousands of pages long, and it has evolved over the last century to deliver things like consumer protection and a whole range of complex corporation law stuff.

Those opposite then go on to argue: 'We're making the wrong change. It should be the race power that's removed first.' First Nations people at the Uluru Statement from the Heart and in the Uluru dialogues were smart about this. They pretty much said, 'If we get one shot at changing the Constitution, we have to do something bigger than that.' As the Uluru Statement from the Heart says, 'Voice, Treaty, Truth'. What we have in this change is something that can connect Indigenous culture and inject this ancient voice and modern Indigenous First Nations culture into our young federation.

I want the Voice because it elevates my own national identity. It speaks to who I am and who I want to be as an Australian. That doesn't mean simply a broad brush of making everyone equal under the one Constitution and treating everyone the same. I want to be able to distinguish First Nations voices and First Nations culture within our national identity. We need to look to First Nations culture for, in the words that Senator Wong used in the chamber today on behalf of Senator Dodson, 'mabu liyan'. That concept means 'strong spirit, good feeling and positive wellbeing'. As I married my wife on Yawuru country in Broome last week there was lots of this feeling. While Uncle Pat couldn't be there, I could feel that strong Yawuru spirit. We had a smoking ceremony, and it really spoke to me, in stark contrast to the kind of childhood I had, where I once—probably one of the first times I'd ever seen or met other First Nations Aboriginal people—thought, 'Oh, they've come in off the reservation,' because it was still in those times, in the 1980s, quite unusual for First Nations people to be visible in many parts of Perth. So I want to be able to hear First Nations voices and have that culture be visible to us all. But they can't do that unless we hear that voice and we make room for it in our national dialogue—unless we listen.

I learnt about listening the hard way from old Johnny Watson, who was a leader in the Noonkanbah protests, a founder of the Kimberley Land Council and a senior Nyikina man—a custodian of culture. As a much younger politician, I wanted to prove myself because of my respect for him, and I simply spoke too much. I needed to listen not just to his words but to the pauses in between. So I have listened closely and carefully to the arguments of those opposite, who have tried to paint a picture of risk and division. They paint a picture that we somehow can't trust First Nations Australia with the privileges and the rights that we would give First Nations people with this Voice.

This has been done too many times in our nation before. I'll quote here from the Native Administration Act in Western Australia, which is, of course, a legacy of control because of colonial laws that sought to ensure that First Nations people could never be trusted. The parts I want to read are really about the punishment of the rest of the community for choosing to fraternise, support or be friends with First Nations people. It says that any person or persons who support or assist a First Nations person, a native, on a reserve shall be punished with a penalty of up to 50 pounds or hard labour for six months or both. A second offence meant hard labour for 12 months or a penalty of 100 pounds. They are quite extraordinary laws that were still in place in Western Australia during the lifetimes of many people in Western Australia who are still alive today. They are the kinds of laws that our dear Uncle Pat was subject to as a child in our state. The laws said:

It shall not be lawful for any person other than a native to enter or remain, or be within the boundaries of a reserve for any purpose whatsoever, unless he is a superintendent or a person acting under his direction or an inspector or a protector or a person authorised in that behalf under the regulations.
I know we've all moved on from those days. Those laws no longer exist, and no-one would argue for anything like that today.

But I want to say to people who oppose this referendum: what does it truly mean to be able to say that we can have an independent, constitutionally enshrined First Nations voice to parliament that can't not be heard—that must be heard? Would it really be such a symbol of division if that were the case? I really think it's, frankly, quite the opposite, because this act does not divide our nation. It heals our nation because it gives our nation an opportunity to look back past the time of Federation or first colonisation, and it gives us a tangible, forthright link to First Nations culture, lore and voice.

We shouldn't remain entirely defined by our post-colonial culture. We should allow First Nations Australians to speak on their own terms—albeit within the conventions of how our parliament will write laws to decide how that should be done; albeit as defined by our Constitution and our norms of government. It's not equal to simply say First Nations people should live by the same laws as everybody else as defined by the Constitution, and that everyone should be the same under it. Why? Because these are laws that are written entirely in a particular post-colonial context. When we deprive ourselves of a First Nations voice, because we say: 'Well, we've all got to be the same. We can only listen according to the norms of how we treat everybody the same,' then we deprive ourselves of a First Nations voice, a rich voice that sits at the heart of our nation and that should be at the heart of our democracy. If this Constitutional reform were to fail then we would all be deprived of that.

First Nations law and culture has existed in our nation for some 60,000 years. There is so much for us all to gain in having a First Nations Voice being able to talk directly to government and our parliament. It is not novel or unique in the context of parliaments around the world or even necessarily in terms of concepts of parliamentary privilege or independence, where every Australian has a right to express their independent voice under privilege. So why not respect that Voice of First Nations people in this parliament— (Time expired)

Senator CHANDLER (Tasmania) (22:12): I rise to speak on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023. The Liberal Party supports the right of Australians to have their say on the Labor Party's attempt to change the Constitution. We support the Australian people having that say, and we are not going to stand in the way of it. But the Labor Party's proposal is divisive and is only being made more divisive by this government's refusal to answer legitimate questions and by their conduct of the 'yes' campaign.

The Labor Party's proposal presents risks which the government cannot honestly address. It asks Australians to place a body into our Constitution without being told what that body will look like, how it will be appointed, and what powers it will have. It tells Australians that they need to vote to make that body a permanent fixture in the Constitution before they have any chance to see how it works and even assess if it will work. Like many others, I believe that implementing different Constitutional arrangements for people of different cultural and racial back grounds is not how we should operate our legal democracy. I also think that it is highly unlikely that embedding a bureaucratic advisory body in the Constitution will actually improve outcomes in communities across Australia which need practical, on-the-ground investment and support. But the proposal put by the government in this referendum is that our nation and the lives of Australians will be made better by more bureaucracy—bureaucracy based on race and identity.

This Labor government has been in power for over a year now, and it has handed down two budgets in that time. The government could have focused on making significant investments on the ground, in the communities, in those two budgets that it's handed down. Instead, what we see is hundreds of millions of dollars being spent on a divisive referendum.

At the moment you can barely turn on a television or switch on the radio without being bombarded with ads trying to coax Australians into voting yes without being given the details to know what they're voting for. The government is being dishonest in the way that it is running this campaign. They are trying to say that this referendum is just about recognition, but that isn't true at all. The Labor referendum is about permanently inserting, into the constitution, a body of unknown composition, with unknown powers, with an unknown effect on how and when governments can make decisions. The government is effectively telling Australians who ask perfectly reasonable questions about what those powers will be and what their impact on executive government will be that they'll have to wait until after they've voted for it, and then the government will come up with the details. Our Constitution is far more precious and important than that.

This Labor government proposal is, by its nature, divisive. As my colleague, Senator Nampijinpa Price, says, 'We are one together, not two divided.' Enshrining in our Constitution a body for only one group of Australians means permanently dividing Australians by race. In doing so, it would set a precedent in this country for more and more focus on race and identity politics, a path which we know will only ever lead to further division. We can already see, in the conduct of this debate, what the Labor government is setting our country up for. Some of the rhetoric directed at those asking legitimate questions and raising legitimate concerns about the proposed Voice and the referendum has, quite frankly, been appalling. There have been incredibly nasty, incredibly personal aspersions cast by 'yes' supporters on others who have a different opinion. If that's happening now, when the government needs your vote, what will it be like when they don't need it?

Disappointingly, much of the vitriol from the 'yes' side has been directed at the coalition's shadow minister for Indigenous affairs, my colleague Senator Nampijinpa Price. They claim to want a voice to parliament, but they don't show any respect for the democratically elected Indigenous voices already in the parliament. So while I respect the right of Australians to have their say, I put on record tonight, in this debate, my strong concerns with the way that this government has conducted itself to date. I say to Australians that if you don't know what you are being asked to vote for then don't let this government railroad you into voting for it.

Senator RICE (Victoria) (22:18): We are here tonight, debating this bill on the stolen lands of the Ngunnawal and Ngambri peoples. I pay respects to their elders, past, present and emerging. As a senator for Victoria, I live and work on the stolen lands of the Wurundjeri people. I also pay respect to their elders, past, present and emerging, and to all First Nations peoples who live on the land that's now called Victoria, that I represent in this place.

Across Australia, First Nations communities have been singing country on unbroken songlines that stretch back through the oldest culture on earth, predating colonisation and the Commonwealth by tens of thousands of years. I pay tribute to their wisdom, their resilience, their strength and their connection with country.

As well as acknowledging the traditional owners, I want to acknowledge the devastating impacts of colonisation and the loss and grief that so many First Nations people and communities feel. The violence and dispossession that were inherent to colonisation have never been fully reckoned with. To quote from a report by the University of Newcastle:

While some frontier massacres were widely publicised, in most cases a code of silence was imposed in colonial communities in the immediate aftermath. Frontier massacres were only referred to indirectly.
… the 'bush slang' word 'dispersal' was often used as a convenient euphemism for 'wholesale massacre'.

Places are also sometimes named after colonists who have committed frontier massacres. These include the town of Bunbury, in Western Australia, named after Lieutenant William Bunbury, who was the key perpetrator in several frontier massacres in 1836 and 1837. We cannot have an honest reckoning with what's needed to work towards justice if we're not willing to acknowledge the acts of violence that began at invasion: the violent appropriation of land, food and water; the systematic persecution, oppression and genocide of First Nations peoples; the intergenerational trauma of colonisation; and the ongoing violence and racism experienced by our first peoples.

I want to acknowledge that I, as a white person, benefit from the entrenched racism and power structures that are built upon that violence. I have white privilege, and I do my best to bring that awareness into my life and work. It's our responsibility as privileged white people to redress the ongoing injustices of colonisation. Some people like to pretend that somehow this is history and not contemporary reality. They try to disconnect it from the debates, arguments and campaigns about and for racial justice today. But, sadly, the injustice of systemic racism is ongoing. But through it all we have seen the strength and resilience of First Nations peoples, people who are part of the oldest continuing culture on the planet. I salute all First Nations peoples and I acknowledge the 11 who are members of our parliament. And I pay tribute to Dorinda Cox in particular, our strong, staunch First Nations spokesperson.

The Greens were the first party to endorse the Uluru Statement from the Heart in full, and we are committed to progressing all elements of the Uluru Statement from the Heart: truth and treaty, Voice. But we can't ignore the fact that there was some controversy surrounding the Uluru process when it occurred in 2017. Some delegates said that they felt their voices had been silenced, and a group of delegates walked out of the summit, demanding a sovereign treaty with an independent sovereign treaty commission. The Greens' support for the Uluru Statement from the Heart reflects both the powerful statement and these concerns that Voice in itself is just one part of the story. We need treaties with our First Nations peoples and treaty-making processes which reflect their sovereignty.

The Greens' preference was for truth-telling and treaty negotiations to have begun first, before Voice—for the Voice to have been constituted when it was clear that there was a real commitment and real action being taken to progress treaties. However, like so many choices that we have to make in this place, we have to make a binary decision as to whether what is on offer is a step forward to what we want to achieve or a step backwards. In essence, do we support the Voice as a step forward towards treaty or reject it as not being enough?
Indigenous activist Celeste Liddle wrote last month how she is, 'Undecided on which way my vote will go', because Voice on its own is not enough. She said:

… after so many years of experience, of living through every single Indigenous body that has existed and seeing them all be ripped apart by one government after another, I am not sure I buy that having one written into the Constitution is going to make a lot of difference.
She notes:
… surely one of the biggest truths we need to be tell in the first place is how the constitution came to be and why it was deliberately written to exclude us.

And given this, is the answer really our inclusion, or is it coming to the table as equals, sitting down and nutting out, as sovereign peoples, treaties that could ensure a better, more inclusive, way forward?
I hear you, sister.

And I hear former Green Senator Lidia Thorpe, who told the chamber earlier this evening that she's voting no for this bill because what's needed is full recognition of sovereignty and treaties. I respect that view, but it's not the view our party room has come to after extensive consultation with First Nations peoples around the country. Our support for this bill is based on a view that the Voice is a step forward, and that a failed referendum would be a huge step backwards in achieving progress towards treaties. So my support, and the Greens' support for the Voice—the Greens' support for the campaigns for yes—are based on trust that the Voice will not be all that there is. As my colleague Senator Cox said in her speech in this debate, securing a 'Yes' vote at the referendum is our next step. It's only the beginning of what's needed to restore First Nations' rights. Not until we see the effective implementation of all three elements of the Uluru statement will we see progress on closing the gap, on ending racial discrimination and achieving self-determination.

It almost goes without saying that we are appalled by the coalition's ongoing opposition to the Voice referendum, looking for new ways to block and derail this conversation, playing politics and dog whistling to their conservative base. If the referendum fails, it will be on their conscience.

We will continue to push the government to make real and meaningful progress on truth and treaty, not to betray the trust that has been put on them. The Prime Minister says he is committed to implementing the Uluru statement in full. And, in the October 2022 budget, the government committed $5.8 million to a Makarrata Commission, but, as yet, we have seen no real action on progress on this.

Other critical steps that the government needs to take to show that they are serious, that they are committed to justice for First Nations peoples to truly close the gaps is to finish unfinished business, to fully implement the remaining recommendations from the 1991 Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the 1997 Bringing them home report on Indigenous child removals. There have been at least 529 lives lost since the royal commission ended in 1991, and Indigenous child removals continue to occur at a much higher rate than non-Indigenous child removals and the gap is not closing.

In setting up the Voice, the government must commit to actually listen to the Voice, listen to the calls to stop locking up Indigenous kids, listen to the voices highlighting the inherent racism in income management, including the latest iteration, the SmartCard. That's a policy that has been strongly opposed by First Nations peoples in the Northern Territory and around the country since it was imposed by the Howard government as part of the intervention. Listen to First Nations peoples about protecting country. Listen to those who have been working for forest protection since colonisation. When governments heedlessly damage native forests through destructive logging, they are destroying First Nations' heritage. Listen to those who are campaigning against the destruction of land and water and climate through fracking and ongoing gas exploration.

In conclusion, yes, the Greens and I are committed to the Voice. We support the campaigns for yes. We want to see a successful referendum, but the test for our government now and ongoing is for the government to listen to the Voice, to listen to the voices of our First Peoples and to commit wholeheartedly to walking side by side with them, achieving treaties that will allow our country to move on together at peace.
Debate adjourned.
ADJOURNMENT
Senator McCARTHY: I move:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
